title: U.S., China reach 'phase 1' of trade deal
text:
SOUNDBITE (ENGLISH) U.S. PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP, SAYING:

"I think this is a deal that's beyond tariffs., I really mean that. I think that world peace....there was a lot of friction between the United States and China and now it's a love fest. That's a good thing."

President Trump - seated in the oval office surrounded by top negotiators from China and the U.S. - announced the two sides had reached a partial trade deal Friday.

He said the world's two biggest economies are closer to ending their trade war.

SOUNDBITE (ENGLISH) U.S. PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP, SAYING:

"We've come to a deal on intellectual property, financial services, a tremendous deal for the farmers a purchase of from $40 billion to $50 billion worth of agricultural products. That would be 2-1/2, 3 times what China had purchased at its highest point so far."

U.S. financial service companies will now have greater access to Chinese customers and China agreed to more transparency around its currency. That's been a point of contention between the two nations since the White House accused China of being a currency manipulator.

Also part of the agreement, which was described by the White House as just phase one, the tariff hike planned for next week on $250 billion worth of Chinese-made goods has been scratched.

But threats for a December tariff on Chinese-made products that have so far been left out of the trade war were not rescinded.

And more importantly - all the current tariffs remain in place.

The bruising 15-month trade war between the U.S. and China has crippled global manufacturing operations and damaged business sentiment around the world.

Speaking through an interpreter, China's top negotiator Vice Premier Liu He said the two sides are making a lot of progress towards a positive direction in their economic relationship and will continue in that effort.

But the two sides still have to tackle thornier issues around intellectual property theft and grumblings about the subsidies Beijing gives to Chinese companies.

He hopes the two sides can work out the final details of this agreement and have something he and China's Xi Jinping can sign when the two meet at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Chile next month.
